A Short Introduction
to Adult Cinema

Pornography has been created by nearly every civilization
since the dawn of mankind. Archeological discoveries have
included sexually explicit drawings on European cave walls
dating from 30,000 B.C. to 10,000 B.C., and pornographic clay
figurines from the Neolithic period, 9,000 B.C. to 7,000 B.C.
The earliest cultures associated sexual acts with supernatural
religious forces. Hinduism, Buddhism, Taoism and Shintoism
all include erotic art as spiritually meaningful parts of their
religions. The Greeks and Romans included sexually explicit
art in their culture and religious beliefs. Advances in technology
would be a boon to pornography and lead to its eventual
blossoming. In 1727, German professor Johann Heinrich
Schulze discovered that silver nitrate darkens when exposed to
sunlight. This discovery would eventually lead to the production
of motion pictures.

The first person to produce a permanent photographic
image was French aristocrat Joseph Nicephore Niepcein in
1827. Following his death in 1833, his partner Louis Daguerre
claimed all credit and re-named the process the Ã¢â‚¬Å“daguerreotype.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½
The first known daguerreotype taken in the United
States is a self-portrait of photographer Robert Cornelius,
dated 1839. By 1850, at least seventy daguerreotype studios
operated in New York City, providing portraits to wealthy
patrons.

From 1884 to 1887 Eadweard Muybridge conducted
experi ments using a series of still cameras which photo graphed
moving subjects, thus creating the illusion of mo tion. His earliest
tests included nude men and women doing things like
walking up stairs or swinging a baseball bat.

Thomas Edison perfected his Ã¢â‚¬Å“kinetoscope,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ the first
device to record actual motion pictures, in 1889. Eastman
Kodak founder George Eastman soon introduced flexible film
that could be used in motion picture cameras. Edison began
shooting his own short films by 1894.
